concept.title: Understanding Fuel Mixture Types
concept.shortdesc: The air-fuel ratio in the carburetor determines whether a mixture is lean or rich, each having distinct characteristics and effects on engine performance.

section.title: Basic Definitions
section.p: Fuel mixtures are classified by their air-to-fuel ratios:

ul.li: Lean mixture: Contains too much air and insufficient gasoline
Rich mixture: Contains too much gasoline and insufficient air

section.title: Effects of Rich Mixtures
section.p: Running an engine with a rich mixture causes several problems:

ul.li: Carbon buildup on cylinders, pistons, and valves
Heavy, black exhaust smoke with strong odor

section.note: Rich mixtures may allow perfect operation at high speeds despite causing problems at lower speeds.

ul.li:
Backfiring through the carburetor due to:
Slow-burning gas in the cylinder
Continued burning when inlet valve reopens
Ignition of gas in the intake
Be as lean as possible while maintaining full engine power
